__data__.text:
Advances in Engineering Software 169 (2022) 103129
2Therefore, it is necessary and useful to utilize a face-based data 
structure based on the dual relationship between the DT and the VD. It 
could provide a platform for obtaining and storing geometric and 
extensive neighborhood information for a set of points with the least 
calculations and more cost-effective than edge-based data structures in 
terms of memory. Moreover, this data structure can be converted to 
other data structures with optimal and linear complexity. Using this data 
structure, an optimal incremental algorithm can be proposed without 
the need for the other structures and pre-processing operations. It is easy 
to understand and implement while can store and update DT and the VD 
information simultaneously with more cost-effective than edge-based 
data structures in terms of memory. This paper provides three versions 
for the proposed data structure based on the dual relationship of DT and 
the VD. Also, a new incremental algorithm based on each version of the 
new data structure with the overall complexity of O(nlogn ) is presented. 
In the following, first, in Section 2, we investigate the types of al-
gorithms and data structures provided for the construction and main -
tenance of the 2D Delaunay triangulation and Voronoi Diagram. In 
Section 3, we describe the new data structure and incremental algorithm 
completely. In Section 4, the proposed algorithm is evaluated by the 
types of point distribution and results are discussed. Finally, Section 5 
concludes the study and future work on the proposed data structure and 
an incremental algorithm will be presented. 
2.Previous research 
Various data structures have been proposed to store information on 
the DT and the VD. The data structures most commonly used to store DT 
and VD information includes:  
- Winged-Edge [11,12] was presented in 1975 by Bruce G. Baumgart. 
In this data structure, to store the information of VD, generally, a 
maximum of 27n-25 integers (n is the number of points) to store 
topological information and 2n-2 bits plus 4n-4 floating-point 
numbers to store metric information is required [1]. In addition, 
the stored information for the edges only is in the order of 24n-24. 
-Doubly Connected Edge List [21], presented by Muller and Pre-
parata in 1977. In this data structure, to keep the topological infor-
mation of the VD, for each edge, 6 integer numbers plus 2 integer 
one-bit numbers (for indexing) [25], One integer is for each vertex 
and one integer for each polygon is required. The memory required 
to store VD information in this data structure is generally from 
27n-25 (memory required only for edge information is in order of 
24n-24). In addition, 4n-4 floating-point numbers are required for 
storing metric information.  
- Quad_Edge [14], introduced by Guibas and Stolfi in 1985, can store 
a graph and its dual graph information. In this data structure, for 
each edge, 8 pointers (integers) and 4 other two-byte integers 
(indexing) are needed to store the topological information of the 
edges [25]. Therefore, the memory required for the Quad_Edge data 
structure to store the topological information of the edges is in the 
order of 36n-36 integer. Hence, the Quad_Edge data structure re-
quires more memory than the Doubly Connected Edge List, while 
more flexibility and ability to store a graph and its dual information 
simultaneously are among its benefits. 
Based on these data structures, several algorithms are proposed for 
constructing the DT and the VD. Based on the classification of Su and 
Drysdale [26], the proposed algorithms are divided into different cate-
gories such as divide and conquer [6,14,27], incremental algorithms [10, 
28–32], Plane Sweep Algorithms [9,15,33]), Convex Hull Based Algorithms 
[34], Gift Wrapping Algorithms [35,36]. 
The algorithms proposed for constructing the DT and the VD are 
often complex in terms of implementation and programming. In the 
meantime, incremental algorithms have the advantage of simplicity and 
ease of implementation and upgrade. In these algorithms, we usually start with a simple VD or triangulation consisting of two or three initial 
points, and gradually add other points to the set.

__data__.text:
Based on these data structures, several algorithms are proposed for 
constructing the DT and the VD. Based on the classification of Su and 
Drysdale [26], the proposed algorithms are divided into different cate-
gories such as divide and conquer [6,14,27], incremental algorithms [10, 
28–32], Plane Sweep Algorithms [9,15,33]), Convex Hull Based Algorithms 
[34], Gift Wrapping Algorithms [35,36]. 
The algorithms proposed for constructing the DT and the VD are 
often complex in terms of implementation and programming. In the 
meantime, incremental algorithms have the advantage of simplicity and 
ease of implementation and upgrade. In these algorithms, we usually start with a simple VD or triangulation consisting of two or three initial 
points, and gradually add other points to the set. Each time a new point 
is added, we update the structure. Thus, adding a new point to the 
structure consists of two main steps: First, searching for the nearest 
neighbor or a triangle containing the added point and then, updating the 
DT and the VD locally. The overall complexity of incremental algorithms 
usually depends on the complexity of the first step. 
For the first step, Most of the algorithms use online routing algo-
rithms in graphs for "walking" operation on vertices or triangles 
[37–39]. In these algorithms, by knowing the point (vertex) of origin 
and the added point, walking from one point to another point (from a 
triangle to another triangle) is carried out using the list of neighbors of 
the point (vertex) of origin at each step. It continues until the cell or 
triangle containing the added point is found. The overall complexity of 
these algorithms is O(̅̅̅n√). For example, Green and Sibson [10] devel -
oped an algorithm with an overall complexity of O(n3/2) and in their 
proposed algorithm, they go to the neighboring point at the shortest 
distance to the newly added point. If the points are added to the struc-
ture in such a way that each added point has a short distance to the 
previously added point, we can significantly reduce the overall 
complexity of the algorithm. The structures used for this purpose include 
Quadtree, Octree, Quaternary Tree, and Kd Trees [40–43]. For example, 
Ohya et al. [43] suggested a pre-processing process based on the Qua-
ternary Tree data structure to arrange the addition of points to the 
structure to decrease the overall complexity of adding points to O(n). 
However, the initial formation of these structures has O(nlogn) time 
complexity. 
In some algorithms, hierarchical triangles are used to reduce the 
complexity of searching for the triangle containing a newly added point 
[8,44–46]. These algorithms start to search for newer triangles con-
taining the added point from the root triangle. The overall complexity of 
these algorithms is O(nlogn) . For example, Guibas, Knuth, and Shariri 
[8] Suggested an algorithm with O(logn) overall complexity to find the 
triangle containing the newly added point by storing the old structures 
of the DT and connecting the old and new triangles by pointers from the 
old triangles to the new triangles. 
With the rapid development of computer hardware, parallel 
computing based on DT has attracted more attention in recent years 
[47–50]. But the need for multi-core CPUs is the limitation of the 
widespread use of the DT or the construction of VD in parallel [40]. 
The proposed data structure in this paper, being more cost-effective 
than edge-based data structures, is the face-based data structure that 
easily provides the appropriate geometric and neighborhood informa -
tion for many applications without the need for subsequent processing. 
It can also be easily converted to edge-based data structures. Moreover, 
in this paper, an incremental algorithm with optimal complexity for 
constructing a DT and VD together based on the proposed data structure 
is proposed. The proposed algorithm is compatible with various types of 
online routing algorithms on Voronoi cells by establishing links among 
the structure of Voronoi cells at the time of their placement in the dia-
gram without the need for preprocessing and structures such as Quad -
tree, Octree, Quaternary Tree, and KD-trees.

__data__.text:
But the need for multi-core CPUs is the limitation of the 
widespread use of the DT or the construction of VD in parallel [40]. 
The proposed data structure in this paper, being more cost-effective 
than edge-based data structures, is the face-based data structure that 
easily provides the appropriate geometric and neighborhood informa -
tion for many applications without the need for subsequent processing. 
It can also be easily converted to edge-based data structures. Moreover, 
in this paper, an incremental algorithm with optimal complexity for 
constructing a DT and VD together based on the proposed data structure 
is proposed. The proposed algorithm is compatible with various types of 
online routing algorithms on Voronoi cells by establishing links among 
the structure of Voronoi cells at the time of their placement in the dia-
gram without the need for preprocessing and structures such as Quad -
tree, Octree, Quaternary Tree, and KD-trees. To perform walking 
operations in the proposed algorithm, separate matrices based on the 
proposed data structure are used, which play the role of storing the 
structure of the Voronoi cell of points at the time of placement in the VD. 
Hence, the storage of information of the old and new structure of Vor-
onoi cells is done separately and is available separately in the 
applications. 
3.The proposed data structure and incremental algorithm 
Like the other incremental algorithms, the proposed algorithm con-
sists of two main phases: Searching for the nearest neighbor and 
upgrading the VD and the DT locally (Algorithm 1). In incremental al-
gorithms, we start with a simple initial structure and gradually add other 
points. When a new point is added, the previous structure of VD and DT P. Shivanasab and R. Ali Abbaspour

__data__.text:
Advances in Engineering Software 169 (2022) 103129
3is updated. The initial structure is constructed by adding 3 or 4 com-
plementary points at a greater distance to the other points of Ƥ. This 
initial structure has 5 points including p1 and 4 complementary points 
added to the set Ƥ. The loop in Algorithm 1 adds points with IDs ’2′to 
’n’, to the structure. According to Algorithm 1, the second phase will be 
performed in two simple steps: Finding the list of added point ’s neigh -
bors and the list of triangles that have lost their Delaunay property, and 
then updating the information of the VD and the DT, which we will 
introduce later (Section 3.3). 
3.1. Data structure 
To construct VD and DT incrementally, it is necessary to have a data 
structure that clearly shows the dual relationship between them. The 
dual relationship between the DT and the VD means that the center of 
each Voronoi cell is a vertex of the DT. Moreover, the center of the 
circumcircle of each Delaunay triangle is a vertex of the VD. Using this 
dual relationship, the face (polygon or vertex) based data structure with 
the minimum required memory is suggested. Assuming a set Ƥ ={p1, p2, 
p3,…, pn} of n points, following the structure of the proposed data 
structure for maintaining the VD and the corresponding DT, is described. 
Fig. 1 shows the DT and VD of 8 points. 
3.1.1. Storing VD and DT information 
The vertices of the VD are the center of the circumcircle of the DT. 
Hence, for each vertex of the VD, which is the center of the circumcircle 
of one of the Delaunay triangles, the coordinates of that vertex and the 
three IDs corresponding to the vertices of the corresponding triangle are 
stored in the proposed data structure. In the proposed data structure, the 
topological information of Delaunay triangles is stored in a matrix called 
Topological Information of Triangles (TIT). This matrix has three col-
umns that store IDs of vertices of each triangle (see Fig. 2-a). 
V1→V2→V3 order for each triangle is counterclockwise. Points with IDs 
higher than 8 in TIT matrix (Fig. 2-a) are complementary points IDs that 
are added to the set of points of Ƥ at the beginning of the incremental 
algorithm. The metric information of Delaunay triangles is stored in a 
matrix which is called Metric Information of Triangles (MIT). MIT ma-
trix has two columns (as can be seen in Fig. 2-b) for storing x and y 
coordinates of the center of the circumcircle of the Delaunay triangles 
(coordinates of Voronoi vertices). In addition, the ID of each triangle is 
equal to the ID of the Voronoi vertex corresponding to that Delaunay 
triangle. The DT has at most 2n-5 triangles, hence the memory 
requirement to store the topological information of the Delaunay triangles is from the order of 3 ×(2n-5) =6n-15 integer, and the metric 
information is from the order of 2 ×(2n-5) =4n-10 floating-point 
numbers. 
In the following, the topological information of the Voronoi cells is 
added to the data structure. The topological information of Voronoi cells 
is stored in separate matrixes for each Voronoi cell. Each Voronoi cell 
corresponds to one point of Ƥ has a Voronoi Matrix (VM) which stores 
the topological information of that Voronoi cell. VM has three columns. 
The list of IDs of vertices of each Voronoi cell is stored in the third 
column of VM of that Voronoi cell, counterclockwise from top to bottom. 
In other words, for the Voronoi cell of point p, the third column in VM 
shows the IDs of the triangles generated by p and its neighboring points 
as counterclockwise from top to bottom. 
Then, the IDs of the other two vertices of the triangle corresponding 
to that row are placed in the first and second columns of the matrix,

__data__.text:
Each Voronoi cell 
corresponds to one point of Ƥ has a Voronoi Matrix (VM) which stores 
the topological information of that Voronoi cell. VM has three columns. 
The list of IDs of vertices of each Voronoi cell is stored in the third 
column of VM of that Voronoi cell, counterclockwise from top to bottom. 
In other words, for the Voronoi cell of point p, the third column in VM 
shows the IDs of the triangles generated by p and its neighboring points 
as counterclockwise from top to bottom. 
Then, the IDs of the other two vertices of the triangle corresponding 
to that row are placed in the first and second columns of the matrix, 
respectively, so that their sequence relative to point p is counterclock -
wise. Fig. 2-c and Fig. 2-d show the VM of points 2 and 6 of Fig. 1, 
respectively. 
The sequence of the IDs in the first or second columns of VM from top 
to bottom show IDs of neighbor points of p and the third column shows 
the sequence of the ID of the Voronoi cell vertices and the Delaunay 
triangles formed by p and neighbors of p counterclockwise. Therefore, 
the number of rows in this matrix is equal to the number of neighbors of 
point p. Each point is on average adjacent to six other points, thus the 
average number of rows in a VD is equal to six. e. (See [10] and [43] for 
proof.) 
According to what has been said, the memory required for all the 
VMs is in order of 6 ×3 ×n =18n integer. Therefore, in general, the TIT 
and VMs need a total of 18n +6n-15 =24n-15 of integers to store the 
topological information of the VD and the DT together. 
Note : The important thing about the VM matrix for each point pi is 
that the first and second columns of VM can be removed and the in-
formation of the first and second columns in each row can be obtained 
through the triangle ID in the third column. Since the ID of vertices of 
triangles is counterclockwise in the TIT matrix, the information of the 
first two columns in the VM matrix can be adapted from the third col-
umn of VM and the TIT matrix during implementation. In this way, the 
required memory can be reduced to 18n-15 in the case of two columns, 
and 12n-15 in the case of one column to store VD and DT information 
together. Winged edge and DCEL data structures require 27n-25 integers 
just to hold information of a Voronoi diagram. Quad-edge data structure, 
which stores VD and DT information together, requires 36n-36 integers. 
Therefore, the required memory to store DT and the VD information in 
the proposed data structure is much lesser than the used edge-based data 
structures. In the following, the proposed incremental algorithm based 
on three different versions of VM of points (three-column, two-column, 
and one-column) is presented. 
3.1.2. Proposed data structure capabilities 
The proposed data structure stores the topological information as 
face-based. Thus, in many applications, neighborhood and geometric 
information about vertices and faces can be obtained without the need 
for extra calculations. In the following, we define functional concepts 
using neighborhood information of points in the proposed data 
structure. 
Definition 1.If we connect the neighboring points of each point, a 
closed polygon similar to the Voronoi cell of that point is created. We 
call it the "second-order Voronoi". We use the second-order Voronoi 
information of each point to establish a connection between the Voronoi 
cells. Fig. 3 shows the second-order Voronoi of point ’10′with a black 
polygon. As a result, a new algorithm for walking on Voronoi cells is 
proposed to find the nearest neighbor to the newly added point. By this 
definition, the first and second columns of each row of the VM of each 
point show the beginning and endpoints of an edge of the second-order 
Voronoi of that point. Thus, the first and second columns of the VM,

5pk that ID of pj is in the first column of the intended row so that the ID of 
the target vertex is in the second column of the intended row. For 
example, in Fig. 3, a vertex of the third-order Voronoi of point ’10′, 
which is the opposite of the edge 11→7 of the second-order Voronoi of 
point ’10′(point ’3′), can be extracted using the VM of points ’11′and 
’7′. In VM of Point ’11′, its second-order Voronoi edges are counter -
clockwise, thus in VM of Point ’11′, edges 3→7 and 7→10 are in two 
consecutive rows from top to bottom. In the row of the VM of point ’11′
with the ID of point ’7′in its second column, the information of triangle 
11–3–7 is located and the ID of point ’3′is in the first column. Similarly, 
the ID of point ’3′is in the second column of the row of the VM of point 
’7′, where point ’11′is in the first column of that row. 
It is worth noting that only a second-order Voronoi is required to 
generate a DT and VD. But in the same way, you can simply use this 
proposed data structure to define higher-order Voronoi and use the 
spatial distribution and geometric information of these distributions for 
different applications (such as clustering and object matching). With the 
proposed data structure, useful neighborhood and geometric informa -
tion used in a variety of applications are easily accessible. The appendix 
shows that this data structure can be easily converted to a Doubly 
Connected Edge List data structure with optimal and linear complexity. 
3.2. Proposed incremental algorithm, version #1 
In the first version of the incremental algorithm for simultaneous 
construction of VD and DT, three columns of VM of points are held. The 
required memory is in order of 24n-15 integers. In the following, 
different parts of the proposed incremental algorithm based on the 
three-column version of VM matrices of points are presented. 
3.2.1. Nearest-neighbor search 
In the proposed data structure, the list of neighbors of each point, 
counterclockwise from top to bottom, is available in the first two col-
umns of the VM of each point, without the need for additional pro-
cessing. Therefore, it is possible to use a variety of walking operations on 
Voronoi points and cells (the vertices of the DT) or triangles (by the TIT) 
through online routing algorithms in graphs. In this paper, we perform a 
walking operation on Voronoi cells (points), in combination with the 
graphs online routing algorithms, in such a way that we first find the 
cell, and then the triangle containing the added point. 
Assuming that Vcur denotes the start point, Vdst denotes the added 
point and N(V cur) denotes the list of neighbors of the start point. In each 
step, movement is toward a point in the list N(V cur) with the shortest 
Euclidean distance to Vdst and in the next step, this neighboring point 
plays the role of Vcur. The condition for stopping and reaching the 
nearest neighbor of the added point (cell containing the added point) is 
that the Euclidean distance between Vcurand Vdst is less than the points of 
the list N(V cur). Fig. 4 shows the operation of walking on Voronoi cells in 
three steps from point ’13′to the added point (p). In the last step (Fig. 4- 
c), considering that the Euclidean distance from point p to point ’11′is 
less than the distance from the neighbors of point ’11′to point p, we 
select point ’11′as the closest neighbor to the added point (Voronoi cell 
containing the added point). 
To find a triangle containing the added point, assuming that the 
nearest neighbor to the added point (found in the steps taken in the 
walking operation) is pi, we look for an edge of second-order Voronoi of 
pi that has " azimuth condition".

Fig. 4 shows the operation of walking on Voronoi cells in 
three steps from point ’13′to the added point (p). In the last step (Fig. 4- 
c), considering that the Euclidean distance from point p to point ’11′is 
less than the distance from the neighbors of point ’11′to point p, we 
select point ’11′as the closest neighbor to the added point (Voronoi cell 
containing the added point). 
To find a triangle containing the added point, assuming that the 
nearest neighbor to the added point (found in the steps taken in the 
walking operation) is pi, we look for an edge of second-order Voronoi of 
pi that has " azimuth condition". 
Definition 3.The "azimuth condition" for any edge of the second- 
order Voronoi of point pi, is defined such that the azimuth of the point 
pi to the added point AZpi→p is between azimuth pi to the beginning point 
and azimuth pi to the endpoint of that edge. The edge for which the 
stated condition is true has an azimuth condition. 
Thus, the triangle corresponding to the edge of the second-order 
Voronoi of the nearest neighbor to the point that satisfies the azimuth 
condition is selected as the triangle containing the added point. In the second phase of the proposed incremental algorithm (updating the VD 
and DT locally), we use the ID of this triangle. 
Note 1: The final triangle of the proposed method, which has an 
azimuth condition, is not always the triangle containing the added point. 
As can be seen in Fig. 5, the nearest neighbor to the added point (p) is 
point ’7′(point p is inside the Voronoi cell of point ’7′). However, the 
triangle which has the azimuth condition (edge 11–3 and triangle 
11–3–7), is not the triangle containing the added point. The proposed 
algorithm for the second phase of the incremental algorithm (local 
updating the VD and DT) is such that there is no need to know the exact 
triangle containing the added point. In this case, based on the proposed 
algorithm for the walking operation, we send the ID of triangle 11–3–7

6as the triangle containing the added point for the second phase of the 
incremental algorithm. As shown in Section 3.3.1, in this manner, the 
local update of the VD and DT will be performed correctly. 
If we want to find the exact triangle containing the added point, it is 
enough to consider the additional condition of being counterclockwise 
11→ 3→ p at the end (Fig. 5). If it was clockwise, then we should look for 
the triangle in front of edge 11–3 (which had the azimuth condition). 
Simply, since the order of the triangles in the VM of points ’11′and ’3′is 
counterclockwise, the ID of this triangle can be found from the VM of 
each of these points. 
The complexity of this algorithm with this process is O(̅̅̅n√). Now, 
using the process of walking on Voronoi cells in the proposed way and 
using the proposed data structure, we take longer steps to the nearest 
neighbor of the added point. 
In this way, we connect the structure of Voronoi cells when they are 
placed in the VD, and in each step, we move from the old structures of 
the VD to the newer structures. We move from "old" Voronoi cells to 
"new" Voronoi cells that are linked to each other based on the chrono -
logical order of their creation. Depending on the proposed data struc-
ture, an auxiliary matrix called "old Voronoi Matrix" (old-VM) can be 
used to make links between old Voronoi cells. In the old-VM, for each 
point, we place the list of its neighbors at the time of its insertion into the 
VD in the form of a column. Therefore, the column of neighbors of any 
point in the old-VM is equal to the first or second column of the VM of 
that point at that time of adding to the structure, and by updating the 
VD; we do not change the neighbors ’ list in the old-VM for any point. 
The second column is initially filled with a value of zero. This column 
acts as a link between old-VM of points. The second column in each row 
of the old-VM of each point pi is filled with the ID of the first point that 
has the least distance to the corresponding point (neighbor) to that row 
compared with the other neighbors of pi when it was added to the 
structure during the walking on Voronoi cells. Thus, a link between a 
neighbor of pi and a newly added point (p) is established. For each 
neighbor in old-VM of pi, we have one link to another point and it won ’t 
change. 
Suppose p1 is the first point added to the structure. According to 
Algorithm2, we start the walking operation from the old-VM of p1. 
’Vcell ’ shows the ID of the cell associated with each step (line1). In line 
3, we find the closest neighbor to the added point (p) among the 
neighbors in old-VM of Vcell (as nold). Then, according to the value 
stated in the second column of the row corresponding to nold (line 4), we 
will have one of these two cases: 1- If the value stated in the second 
column is zero, it means that no link between nold and any other point is 
established yet. Thus, we establish a link between nold and the newly 
added point (p) by replacing the ID of the added point (p) with zero in that row, and the walking operation in the old-VM will be completed 
(line 6). Then we go to the new structure of the Voronoi cell of Vcell or 
VM of Vcell (lines 9 to 16). 2- If the value specified in the second column 
is not zero, it means that a link between nold and another point is 
established. So, we step into the point whose ID is specified in the second 
column (line 8) and use its old-VM to continue the walking operation.

Thus, we establish a link between nold and the newly 
added point (p) by replacing the ID of the added point (p) with zero in that row, and the walking operation in the old-VM will be completed 
(line 6). Then we go to the new structure of the Voronoi cell of Vcell or 
VM of Vcell (lines 9 to 16). 2- If the value specified in the second column 
is not zero, it means that a link between nold and another point is 
established. So, we step into the point whose ID is specified in the second 
column (line 8) and use its old-VM to continue the walking operation. 
In the new structure of the Voronoi cell of Vcell, assuming that pn is a 
neighbor from the first column of VM of Vcell that have a minimum 
distance to p (line 10), if the distance pn to p is less than the distance 
Vcell to p, we step into the cell pn (line 12). Otherwise, the triangle 
corresponding to the edge of the second-order Voronoi of Vcell, which 
has the azimuth condition, is considered as a triangle containing the 
added point (line 15) and the search ends (Line 16). 
In this way, to take longer steps, for each neighbor in the old-VM of 
each point, we established a link to one of the points that were added to 
the VD. Then, we modified the walking operation based on VM and old- 
VM of added points and the links established between them. Therefore, 
in each step, we go from older versions of VD to newer versions. The 
memory required to store the old-VM of points is of the order of 2 ×6 ×
n =12n. The more point insertion is randomized, the algorithm per-
forms better (Based on the type of walking operation and the links be-
tween the old-VM matrices). 
Fig. 6 shows the established links among old-VM of 20 Voronoi cells. 
Suppose point p is added to the diagram. To find the Voronoi cell con-
taining the added point, suppose we start walking from point 1. Point 1 
has 4 links to old-VM of points 2, 3, 7, and 4 (Fig. 6.b, the second col-
umn). Also, based on the first column of old-VM of point 1, it has four 
complementary points (21, 22, 23, and 24) as its neighboring points at 
the time of its placement on the Voronoi diagram. Checking the neigh -
boring points listed in the old-VM of point 1 and the links in the second 
column, based on the proposed algorithm, we step into point 2. Among 
the neighboring points listed in the first column of the old-VM of point 2, 
point 1 has the minimum distance to the added point. Since there is an 
established link in the second column of the corresponding row of point 
1 in the old-VM of point 2 (third row in Fig. 6.c), we step to point 9. 
Among the neighboring points of point 9 at the time of its placement into 
the Voronoi diagram (Fig. 6.d, the first column), point 8 has the mini-
mum distance to the added point. Since there is not any established link 
in the second column of the corresponding row, we establish a link be-
tween the added point and point 8 (dashed arrow in Fig. 6.a) by 
replacing zero with the ID of the added point in the second column of the 
row corresponding to point 8 in the old-VM of point 9 (fourth row). 
Finally, using the VM of point 8 (Fig. 6.e), the Voronoi cell containing 
the added point will be determined. 
Note 2: The proposed idea to find the cell containing the added point 
in this article is similar to the idea proposed by Guibas et. all in 1992 [8]. 
They established appropriate links between "old" and "new" triangles. 
Each "old" triangle is connected to two or three "newer" triangles, based 
on their proposed structure. Then they trace all triangles that contain the 
added point, in chronological order of their creation. Their proposed 
idea has overall time complexity in order of O(n log n).

Finally, using the VM of point 8 (Fig. 6.e), the Voronoi cell containing

Note 2: The proposed idea to find the cell containing the added point 
in this article is similar to the idea proposed by Guibas et. all in 1992 [8]. 
They established appropriate links between "old" and "new" triangles. 
Each "old" triangle is connected to two or three "newer" triangles, based 
on their proposed structure. Then they trace all triangles that contain the 
added point, in chronological order of their creation. Their proposed 
idea has overall time complexity in order of O(n log n). In this article, we 
have "old" and "new" Voronoi cells that are linked to each other based on 
the chronological order of their creation. Guibas et. all used the notion of 
the scope of each triangle, that is the number of sites contained in the 
interior of the circumcircle of the desired triangle, to prove the time 
complexity of their idea. Similarly, we define the scope of each Voronoi 
cell to be the number of points in the interior of the boundary of the 
second-order Voronoi of each Voronoi cell. To quote Guibas et. all, "A 
triangle X Y Z of scope k can be charged by at most k sites. It is also plain 
that no triangle can be charged more than once by the same site. 
Moreover, a necessary condition that a triangle X Y Z is charged at all is 
that it arises as a Delaunay triangle at some stage during the incremental 
construction". Similar explanations are credible for Voronoi cells in the 
proposed idea in this research. Interested readers could refer to refer-
ence [8], lemma 2.1, lemma 2.2, lemma 2.3, and Section 3 for more 
details and proofs.

Advances in Engineering Software 169 (2022) 103129
73.2.2. Update VD and DT locally 
By adding a new point, the structure of the Voronoi cells in the 
neighboring points of the added point changes. In addition, some tri-
angles go out of the Delaunay property (i.e., the added point is located 
inside the circumcircle of those triangles), Hence, at this step, we need to 
replace the new Delaunay triangles formed by the added point with the 
triangles that have missed Delaunay property in addition to updating the 
Voronoi cells of the added point neighbors. The edges of the VD are a set 
of points with the characteristic that for any two points pi and pj of the Ƥ 
set that their Voronoi cells are adjacent, these points on the common 
edge of the cell of pi and pj are placed at equal distances from points pi 
and pj. Thus, the common edge of the Voronoi cell at two neighbor points 
is the perpendicular bisector of the line joining those points. By drawing 
the perpendicular bisector lines of the added point and its neighbor 
points and calculating the intersection of these lines, the Voronoi cell of 
the added point can be obtained. 
The part of the Voronoi cell of the neighboring points that is inside 
the Voronoi cell of the added point must be removed from the Voronoi 
cell of those points. With these explanations, the triangles whose center 
of the circumcircle is inside the Voronoi cell of the added point lose their 
Delaunay property and must be removed from the matrix of Delaunay 
triangles (TIT and MIT) and replaced by the triangles generated by the 
added point and its neighboring points. Fig. 7-a shows the Voronoi cell 
at point (p) and the intersection of its edges with the edges of neigh -
boring Voronoi cells (points a, b, c, and d). The common vertex of the 
Voronoi cell of the three points ’11′, ’10′and ’14′(center of the circumcircle of triangle 11–10–14) and the common vertex of the Vor-
onoi cell of three points ’14′, ’15′and ’11′(the center of the circumcircle 
of the triangle 14–15–11) is inside the Voronoi cell of point p. Therefore, 
we must remove these vertices and their corresponding triangles from 
the VD and the DT. In the following, we will summarize updating the VD 
and the DT in two simple steps. In the first step, an algorithm to obtain 
the list of neighboring points of the added point, the edges of the Vor-
onoi cell of the added point, and the triangles that lose their Delaunay 
property are proposed with a complexity of O(1). Then, we remove the 
triangles that have lost their Delaunay property from the VM of their 
corresponding vertices at the end of the first step. Then we prove the 
validity of the proposed algorithm and procedure. In the second step, we 
update the VD and the DT, locally. In addition, from finding the nearest 
neighbor phase (Section 3.2), we have the Voronoi cell and the triangle 
containing the added point as the input to this step. 
3.2.2.1. Finding the nearest neighbors and non-Delaunay triangles. The 
vertices of the triangles whose center of the circumcircle is inside the 
Voronoi cell of the added point are the neighboring points of the added 
point. Because the center of the circumcircle of the triangle formed by all 
three points is the common vertex of the Voronoi cell of those three 
points, and because it is inside the Voronoi cell of the added point, a part 
of the Voronoi cell of these three points is also inside the Voronoi cell of 
the added point. Therefore, in Algorithm 3, the proposed algorithm, 
generally, first inserts the sides of a triangle containing the added point 
into a stack structure. It then examines the Delaunay property of the 
Fig. 6.old-VM links (blue arrows) and matrices.

8right triangles of each side in the stack matrix and takes the neighbors of 
the added point from the non-Delaunay triangles, counterclockwise, and 
updates the stack matrix to examine the surrounding triangles by the 
sides of the non-Delaunay triangles. 
Let’s assume that the triangle containing the added point has vertices 
of V1, V2, and V3, in counterclockwise order, we place the vertices of the 
beginning and the end of each side in each row of the stack matrix in 
such a way that they are counterclockwise relative to the third vertex 
(line 1 of the pseudo-code in Algorithm 3). For example, for the 
mentioned triangle, the sides are placed in each row as (V1,V2) and (V2, 
V3) and (V3,V1). Each side in this matrix represents the triangle to the 
right of this side and the center of its circumcircle should be checked for 
the Delaunay property of the triangle. Then, we put the ID of the triangle 
containing the added point in the list of non-Delaunay triangles (line 2). 
Suppose N is one of the vertices of a triangle added to the list of non- 
Delaunay triangles whose ID is in the first element of the stack matrix 
(line 3). In this case, N is one of the neighbors of the added point (see the 
proof at the end of this section) which is added to the list of neighbors in 
line 4. 
For the line connecting N to the added point (Lp,N), we calculate its 
perpendicular bisector (PLp,N) and the azimuth of the midpoint Lp,N, 
called m (AZ m → p) and store the calculated perpendicular bisector in-
formation in the perpendicular bisector (PL) list (line5). We now enter 
the loop examining the Delaunay property of the surrounding triangles 
(line6). If we find the right triangle of the side in the first row of the stack 
(Tright), since N is the first element of this row, it is also one of the vertices 
of this triangle (line 8). The center of the circumcircle of the triangle 
Tright(Tcenter) is placed inside the Voronoi cell of the added point if the 
absolute value of the acute angle between the vector connecting m to p 
and the vector connecting m to Tcenter is less than 90◦. 
At this phase, if the Tcenter is inside the Voronoi cell p (line 12), we 
add the ID of the Tright to the list of non-Delaunay triangles (line 13). 
Then, we add the other two sides (not common to the side of the first row 
of the stack) after removing the first row of the stack (Line 14), coun-
terclockwise, to the beginning of the stack in a way that a side with the 
initial vertex N is in the first row of the stack (Line 15). Thus, N (the first 
element of the stack) does not change by deleting the first row of the 
stack and adding two new sides to it. 
The value of N changes if the Tcenter is not inside the p Voronoi cell 
(line 16). In this case, we delete only the first row of the stack (line 17). 
Now, the new value of N is different from the last ID in the list of 
neighbors of p. Then, in the next iteration of the ’while ’ loop, the 
perpendicular bisector and m will be calculated with respect to the new 
N (lines 10 and 11). 
By repeating the above procedure, with the least number of checked 
triangles, we will have the list of neighbors of p in a counterclockwise 
sequence at the end. The complexity of the expressed algorithm is of the 
order of O (1). Algorithm 4 also shows two different algorithms for 
finding the right triangle of each side, according to the proposed data 
structure. 
To prove that the procedure works correctly and the edges of the 
Voronoi cell and the list of neighbors of the added point are obtained 
correctly, it is sufficient to show two following facts. Firstly, the stack 
matrix is first filled with the nearest neighbors of the added point.

__data__.text:
By repeating the above procedure, with the least number of checked 
triangles, we will have the list of neighbors of p in a counterclockwise 
sequence at the end. The complexity of the expressed algorithm is of the 
order of O (1). Algorithm 4 also shows two different algorithms for 
finding the right triangle of each side, according to the proposed data 
structure. 
To prove that the procedure works correctly and the edges of the 
Voronoi cell and the list of neighbors of the added point are obtained 
correctly, it is sufficient to show two following facts. Firstly, the stack 
matrix is first filled with the nearest neighbors of the added point. 
Secondly, checking the center of the circumcircle of each triangle is 
performed through a perpendicular bisector, which is, by definition, one 
of the edges of the Voronoi cell of the added point. Thus, it is the nearest 
edge to the center of the circumcircle of the triangle. To prove the first 
case, consider that in VD, three edges are joined to each vertex of the VD. 
This means that the minimum number of edges of each Voronoi cell is 
three. Therefore, the three points that make the triangle containing the 
added point are the primary neighbors of that point and are the closest 
points to the added point. 
Moreover, in the case where the point on the cell containing the 
added point is not in the triangle containing the added point (e.g. the 
point p is inside the Voronoi cell of point ’7′and the triangle 8–3–11 in Fig. 5), we send the triangle in front of the triangle containing the added 
point p as the input of this step (Triangle 7–11–3 in Fig. 5) according to 
Section 3.2. In this case, since one of the vertices of the sent triangle is 
the nearest neighbor to the added point p (point 7 in Fig. 5) and the other 
two points are common vertices with the main triangle containing the 
added point; the neighboring points of the added point are located in the 
stack matrix. Therefore, the ID that we put as the first neighbor in the list 
of neighboring points of the added point (N) is definitely one of the 
neighbors of the added point, and the first perpendicular bisector 
calculated by this neighbor is definitely one of the edges of the Voronoi 
cell of the added point. 
For the second case, consider that we examine the center of the 
circumcircle of the triangles with respect to the perpendicular bisector 
calculated from the first element of the first row of the stack matrix, and 
it is one of the vertices of that triangle. Moreover, the points whose IDs 
enter the stack matrix are the vertices of the triangles that are located 
inside the Voronoi cell of the added point. Thus, they are neighbors of 
the added point. Thus, firstly, N takes the IDs of the neighboring points 
of the added point, and secondly, the triangle that is tested by the 
perpendicular bisectors of N and p at each step is a triangle that ID of one 
of its vertices is in the first element of the removed row. 
Note 3: The algorithm proposed in this paper for the second step is 
similar to the procedure proposed by Green and Sibson in [10] for 
updating the Voronoi diagram locally. The main difference is that in the 
proposed method of Green and Sibson, the locations where perpendic -
ular bisectors meet the edges of the Voronoi cells are calculated and 
from them, the list of the nearest neighbors is obtained. But in our 
proposed method, which is based on a non-edge-based data structure, 
first, the neighboring points are found counterclockwise and the vertices 
of the Voronoi cell of added point are calculated from the perpendicular 
intersection of two consecutive points in the list of nearest neighbors. 
Usually, similar previous research checks if the added point is inside the 
circumference of neighboring triangles. On the contrary, in the proposed 
method, relying on the proposed baseline data structure and considering 
the dual relationship between Delaunay triangulation and the Voronoi 
diagram, we check if the center of the circumferential circle of the 
surrounding triangles is inside the Voronoi cell of the added point. 
Checking is also carried out in such a way that the list of the nearest 
neighbors to the added point of the triangles that have lost their 
Delaunay property is extracted counterclockwise.

__data__.text:
But in our 
proposed method, which is based on a non-edge-based data structure, 
first, the neighboring points are found counterclockwise and the vertices 
of the Voronoi cell of added point are calculated from the perpendicular 
intersection of two consecutive points in the list of nearest neighbors. 
Usually, similar previous research checks if the added point is inside the 
circumference of neighboring triangles. On the contrary, in the proposed 
method, relying on the proposed baseline data structure and considering 
the dual relationship between Delaunay triangulation and the Voronoi 
diagram, we check if the center of the circumferential circle of the 
surrounding triangles is inside the Voronoi cell of the added point. 
Checking is also carried out in such a way that the list of the nearest 
neighbors to the added point of the triangles that have lost their 
Delaunay property is extracted counterclockwise. Thus, all the proper -
ties of Delaunay triangulation and its dual (i.e., Voronoi diagram) are 
preserved and this dual relationship is exploited. Moreover, checking 
the center of the circumference of each triangle is done through a point 
that is one of the vertices of the triangle itself. Hence, checking the 
center of the circumference of each triangle is performed with high ac-
curacy and reliability. Thus, the proposed idea finds the list of the 
nearest neighbors of the added point alongside the id of the triangles 
that lost their Delaunay property, correctly. 
At the end of the first step, for each vertex of the triangles in the list of 
removable triangles, we remove the row corresponding to that triangle 
from the VM of that vertex of the triangle (lines 18 to 20 in Algorithm 3). 
By removing these rows, second-order Voronoi and the structure of the 
VM of neighboring points are altered and become incomplete. In the 
third step, we fill this gap with the new Delaunay triangles and the new 
neighbor of these points (added point). 
3.2.2.2. Update the VM of points, TIT, and TIM. By going through the 
two previous sections, we have the list of added point neighbors 
(counterclockwise) and the list of removable triangles. Every two 
consecutive points in the added point neighbor list, with an added point, 
generate a new triangle. In addition, the newly generated triangles have 
a common vertex at the added point. According to Algorithm 5, we will 
have a new triangle for every two consecutive neighbors (niandn i +1) in 
the list of neighbors of p (line 2). The center of the circumcircle of this 
triangle is obtained from the intersection of PLp,ni and PLp,ni+1 P. Shivanasab and R. Ali Abbaspour

9perpendicular bisectors (members of the list of perpendicular bisectors) 
(line 3), because the center of the circumcircle of each triangle is the 
point where the perpendicular bisectors of that triangle intersect. 
By adding a new point p, the number of new Delaunay triangles is 
greater than the number of triangles that have lost their Delaunay 
property. If we remove the row related to a triangle from the TIT and 
TIM, the row number (ID) of the next triangles of that row changes. To 
prevent the row numbers of the other triangles from changing, we 
replace the removable triangles with new triangles and add the 
remainder to the end of the TIT and MIT (lines 4 to 10). 
In the following, we will update and complete the structure of the 
VM of the new triangle vertices. Considering that each neighbor in the 
list of neighbors of the desired point is at the end and beginning of two 
consecutive edges of the second-order Voronoi of that point. Thus, each 
neighbor is respectively in the second and first columns of two consec -
utive rows corresponding to these edges in the VM of that desired point. 
First the Voronoi matrix of point ni +1 and the added point p in the 
first ‘for’ loop (lines 2 to 19) are updated. The VM matrix of point ni is 
then updated in a separate ‘for’ loop (lines 20 to 22). To update and 
complete the VM of ni +1, in the first column, we search for the ID of the 
ni (line 11) and put the information on the new triangle in the corre -
sponding row, and shift the rest of the rows (Line 13). Cells belonging to 
points that are members of the Convex Hull of Ƥ have no closed 
boundary, but the other cells have a definite and convex boundary 
(points 1, 6, 7, 8, 4, and 3 in Fig. 1 are members of the convex hull). If ni 
+1 is one of the complementary points of the set Ƥ, due to the non- 
closure of the sequence of the second-order Voronoi edges of the com-
plementary points, sometimes the search for the point ni in the first 
column of VM of ni +1 is inconclusive. If ni +1 is one of the comple -
mentary points of the set Ƥ, we insert the information of the new triangle 
at the end of the VM of the point ni +1 (line 16). Also, the row number of 
the VM matrix of point ni +1, where the information of the new triangle 
(p-ni-ni +1) is placed, is saved at ni +1.rowNumber parameter of the point 
ni +1 (lines 14 and 17). The rowNumber parameter of the points in 
Neighbor_List is used to complete the VM of points in the second ‘for’ 
loop. At the end of the first ‘for’ loop, we add the information of the new 
triangle to the end of the VM of p. To update the information of the old- 
VM of p, we add the ID of ni in the first column and the zero in the second 
column to the end of the old-VM of p (lines 18 and 19). 
In the second ‘for’ loop during the updating the VM for point ni for 
each new triangle, the row number (in which the information of the new 
triangle (p-ni-ni +1) must be placed) is specified according to the 
parameter ni.rowNumber and There is no need to the ‘find’ operation in 
the VM matrix of point ni. The parameter ni.rowNumber can be used 
because each neighboring point in the Neighbor_List (let’s assume it is n) 
list is in two consecutive triangles formed by the new triangle, added by 
the point p and its nearest neighbors. In the first ‘for’ loop, each point in 
the Neighbor_List list plays the role of point ni in iteration and the role of 
point ni +1 in the next iteration. In fact, in the last step of the proposed 
incremental algorithm, the VM matrix of points is updated twice. Each 
time for one of the new triangles that point n is one of its vertices.

__data__.text:
The parameter ni.rowNumber can be used 
because each neighboring point in the Neighbor_List (let’s assume it is n) 
list is in two consecutive triangles formed by the new triangle, added by 
the point p and its nearest neighbors. In the first ‘for’ loop, each point in 
the Neighbor_List list plays the role of point ni in iteration and the role of 
point ni +1 in the next iteration. In fact, in the last step of the proposed 
incremental algorithm, the VM matrix of points is updated twice. Each 
time for one of the new triangles that point n is one of its vertices. The 
two new triangles, where n is the vertex of both, are in two consecutive 
rows in the VM matrix of point n. Therefore, the information of the 
triangle p-ni-ni +1 in the VM matrix of point ni can be placed in the row 
before the row in ni +1.rowNumber (lines 20 to 22). 
3.3. Proposed incremental algorithm, version #2 
In the second version of the proposed data structure, the second 
column of the VM matrix of points is removed. Thus, the first column in 
the VM matrix of point p is the list of nearest neighbors, and the second 
column is the list of triangles formed by p and the nearest neighbors of p. 
The memory required for the second version of the proposed data 
structure is of the order of 18n-15. The general procedure of the pro-
posed incremental algorithm based on the second version of the pro-
posed data structure is the same as the first version. The difference is that in the first version, the ID of the first and the end points of the second- 
order Voronoi of each point was located at the first and second col-
umns of the VM matrix. In the second version of the proposed data 
structure, wherever there is a need for the endpoint ID of an edge of the 
second-order Veronese point (for example, to check the azimuth con-
dition), it should be noted that the endpoint ID of each edge of the 
second-order Voronoi cell is saved in the first column of the next row, 
hence, it can be easily extracted. Also, due to the changes in the second 
version of the proposed data structure, it is not possible to use both 
methods of Algorithm 4, and this algorithm is edited as follows: 
Algorithm 6. 
Other parts of the proposed algorithm are the same as the first 
version. As it can be seen, the second and first versions are not much 
different in terms of complexity, and the only difference is the addition 
of some ‘If conditions ’ to the code. 
3.4. Proposed incremental algorithm, version #3 
In the third version of the proposed data structure, only the list of 
triangles formed by each point and its nearest neighbors in a top-down 
column is stored counterclockwise. As a result, the memory required for 
this version of the data structure is of the order of 12n-15 integers. The 
general procedure of the nearest neighbor search (Algorithm 2) in the 
third version is the same as the previous two versions. The difference is 
that in lines 9 to 16, it is necessary to extract the ID of the neighboring 
points or the beginning and end points of the second-order Voronoi (to 
check the azimuth condition), from the TIT matrix and the row corre -
sponding to the triangle stored in the VM matrix. Due to the anti- 
clockwise order of the points in the TIT matrix from the first column 
to the third column, the desired neighbor or the ID of the beginning and 
end points of the second-order Voronoi can be easily extracted. Algo-
rithm 7 shows the edited version of Algorithm 3 corresponding to the 
third version of the proposed data structure. A column is added to the 
stack structure. When the information of the two edges of a triangle is 
placed in the stack matrix to check their right triangles, the ID of the 
triangle corresponding to those two edges is also placed in the third 
column of each row (lines 1 and 16). The IDs in the third column are 
used to find the right triangle of each edge in Algorithm 8. Algorithm 8 is 
the edited version of Algorithm 4 based on the third version of the data 
structure. In line 9, the triangle ID mentioned in the third column is sent 
to the FindRightTriangleOfEdge function.

rithm 7 shows the edited version of Algorithm 3 corresponding to the 
third version of the proposed data structure. A column is added to the 
stack structure. When the information of the two edges of a triangle is 
placed in the stack matrix to check their right triangles, the ID of the 
triangle corresponding to those two edges is also placed in the third 
column of each row (lines 1 and 16). The IDs in the third column are 
used to find the right triangle of each edge in Algorithm 8. Algorithm 8 is 
the edited version of Algorithm 4 based on the third version of the data 
structure. In line 9, the triangle ID mentioned in the third column is sent 
to the FindRightTriangleOfEdge function. In the pseudo-code of Algo-
rithm 7 and on line 19, the Tright triangle ID is stored in the leftTriangle 
parameter corresponding to the last point added to the Neighbor_List list. 
The IDs stored in the leftTriangle parameter are used in the last step, i.e., 
updating VD and DT locally, to update the VM matrix corresponding to 
the point ni +1 in each iteration of the first ‘for’ loop. Because the tri-
angle stored in ni.leftTriangle is a triangle in which the information of the 
new triangle p-ni-ni +1 must be placed in the row before it, and their 
order is counterclockwise relative to the point ni +1. In line 9 of the 
pseudo-code of Algorithm 5, the row number of the VM matrix of point 
ni +1, which is equal to ni.leftTriangle , is stored in the parameter k. All 
parts of Algorithm 5 except line 9 do not change for the third version. 
Thus, to reduce the volume of the article, pseudo-code is omitted. 
4.Results and discussion 
First, the performance of the proposed incremental algorithm based 
on the three-column version of the proposed data structure for different 
point distributions is evaluated. Then, the performance of the proposed 
incremental algorithm based on all three versions of the proposed data 
structure is evaluated. The proposed incremental algorithm was imple -
mented in MATLAB R2020b software, in the system with a 2.5 GHz core 
i5 processor and 12 GB memory. 
To evaluate the performance of the proposed incremental algorithm 
based on the three-column version of the data structure, we first 
examined the number of steps taken in the nearest neighbor search P. Shivanasab and R. Ali Abbaspour

10phase for different point distributions. Different datasets of 217 to 222 
points with uniform and non-uniform distribution are generated (Fig. 8). 
Table 1 describes the distributions of points where some distributions 
are taken from [26]. In this table, U(a,b) represents the uniform distri -
bution in the range a to b and N(µ,s) represents the normal distribution 
with mean µ and standard deviation s. 
Fig. 9 shows a graph of the average number of steps per number of 
points for different types of point distributions. In the next step, the run 
time of the proposed algorithm (without counting the number of steps) 
per point, i.e., (number of points/run time), was examined for different 
types of point distributions. Fig. 10 shows the graphs (run-time per 
point/number of points) for different distributions. 
As stated in Section 3, the average number of neighbors for each 
Voronoi cell in a Voronoi diagram is six. In addition, studies show that 
the number of neighbors of each Voronoi cell at the time of adding to the 
structure, on average, remains constant (i.e. equal to 6) as the number of 
points increases. Thus, the proposed algorithm connects the Voronoi 
cells at the time they are placed into the structure in a way that each 
Voronoi cell, on average, is connected to 6 other Voronoi cells. 
Evaluations for different point distributions show an increase in the 
number of steps and run-time per point insertion as the point distribu -
tion leaves the uniform distribution. It can be seen from Figs. 9 and 10 
that for the same number of points, normal and uniform distributions 
cost less time and steps per point than the other distributions among 
different point distributions. On the other hand, for the same number of 
points, cross and line distributions cost more time and steps per point 
than the other distributions. The maximum number of taken steps and 
time per point insertion belongs to cross distribution. 
However, with increasing the number of points, the slope of the 
changes in the mean of taken steps and the slope of change in run time 
per point is almost the same for different types of point distribution. This 
indicates the high robustness of the proposed algorithm against different 
point distributions. Finally, the temporal behavior of the proposed al-
gorithm by increasing the number of points, confirms the time complexity and robustness of the proposed algorithm. 
To compare the run time of the proposed algorithm based on three 
different versions of the data structure, the average run time of insertion 
of a point in the diagram to the number of points for Uniform and Cross 
distributions is presented in Figs. 11 and 12, respectively. As can be seen 
from the figures, the slope of the graphs is the same for all three versions 
of the proposed data structure, indicating the same time complexity for 
all three versions of the data structure. On the other hand, the time

of the proposed data structure is slightly different from the first version. 
On the other hand, the required memory according to the second version 
is equal to 18n-15 and according to the first version is equal to 24n-15, 
which is a significant difference. Considering the run time and memory 
required based on the first and second versions of the proposed data 
structure, it can be concluded that the performance of the second version 
is more cost-effective than the other two versions. Because the time

Moreover, the memory difference between these two versions is equal to

. FindNearestNeighbor.  
Input: p (added point p ϵ Ƥ) 
Output: id of Voronoi cell and triangle containing p 
1: Vcell:=p1.ID; /* ID of the cell, associated with each step */ 
/* ############### Start walking from old-VM of Vcell 
############### */ 
2: while (true) do 
3:pnold:=find a neighbor from the first column of old-VM of Vcell that have a 
minimum distance to p; 
4:if (pnold.secondColumnsId =0) then 
5: pnold.secondColumnsId :=p.ID; 
6: break; 
7:else 
8: Vcell:=pnold.secondColumnsId ;
/* ############### Then, continue walking using VM of Vcell 
############### */ 
9: while (true) do 
10: pn:=find a neighbor from the first column of VM of Vcell that have a minimum 
distance to p; 
11: if (pn.D <D) then /*D is distance between Vcell and p*/ 
12: Vcell:=pn.ID; 
13: D:=calculate Euclidean distance between p and the point with ID equal to 
Vcell; 
14: else 
15: T_id:=check Azimuth Condition to find triangle containing p; 
16: break;

__data__.text:
Advances in Engineering Software 169 (2022) 103129
12memory). Hence, the percentage of memory improvement required is 
greater than the percentage of increase in runtime in both cases. 
Another point about the proposed data structure is that after making 
the VD and the DT by the first two versions, one or two columns related 
to the information of the second-order Voronoi edges can be removed 
and only the column related to the ID of the triangles is kept. In this way, 
the information of the DT and the VD is stored in a memory of the order 
of 12n-15, and the information of the other two columns of the VM 
matrices can be easily extracted by the information of the third column 
and the TIT matrix with the complexity of O(n). 
5.Conclusion and future work 
In this paper, based on a new data structure proposed for storing 
information of the 2D VD and DT, a simple incremental algorithm with a 
complexity of O(nlogn ) is proposed, which is robust with respect to the different point distribution. The three-column version of the proposed 
data structure requires memory in order of 24n-15 integers to store the 
topological information of the DT and VD in separate matrices that 
extensive geometric and neighborhood information can be easily 
extracted from them. The required memory of the proposed data 
structure can be reduced to 18n-15 integers based on the two-column 
version or to 12n-15 integers based on the one-column version. Any-
way, it is more cost-effective in terms of memory than the previous edge- 
based data structures to store the information of VD and DT together. 
Using the one-column and two-column versions, the percentage of 
memory improvement required (50% and 25%, respectively) is greater 
than the percentage of increase in runtime (24% and 4% approximately, 
respectively) compared with the three-column version. Hence, the per-
centage of memory improvement required is greater than the percentage 
of increase in runtime in both cases. The appropriate version of the data 
structure can be selected based on the limitations of the application in 
terms of memory or execution time, and this shows the high flexibility of 
the proposed data structure. It was also shown in the Appendix that this 
data structure could be easily converted to a DCEL data structure with 
optimal and linear complexity. Also, the proposed data structure and 
incremental algorithm could be useful for some applications in which 
subsequent processing should be used to extract the geometric and 
neighborhood information of the desired points, or applications that 
need both VD and DT together. 
To reduce the overall complexity of the incremental algorithm, by an 
auxiliary matrix based on the proposed data structure, with the required 
memory of order 12n, an operation is proposed to walk on Voronoi cells 
with a complexity of order O (logn), so that in each step, we move from 
the old Voronoi cells structure to the newer Voronoi cells structure. In 
the evaluation and testing of the algorithm, it was shown that the 
number of taken steps is of an order of O (logn). Also, with increasing the 
number of points, the slope of the changes in the mean of taken steps and 
the slope of change in run time per point insertion is almost the same for 
different types of point distribution. This indicates the high robustness of 
the proposed algorithm against different point distributions. Conse -
quently, the proposed algorithm has an optimal time complexity O 
(nlogn ) without pre-processing and the use of ancillary structures. 
Some future work of the presented research:  
•In the proposed method for connection between Voronoi cells and 
due to the flexibility and high efficiency of the proposed data 
structure, more innovative ideas can be used to increase efficiency 
and improve time complexity. For example, future work could 
include examining the effect of increasing the number of links from 
one point to the other points at the time of placement in the VD. In 
the method proposed in this paper, each point at the time of place -
ment in the VD, for each of its neighbors, is a connecting point 
(second column of the old-VM). Can increasing the number of links 
per each neighbor of points, be efficient for different types of dis-
tribution or specific distribution of points? In this case, an additional 
condition can be added to the walking operation, such as going to a 
point with less distance from the added point, among points con-
nected to each neighbor, or other similar conditions.

14Appendix 
In the Doubly Connected Edge List (DCEL) data structure, each edge 
is considered two half-edges in opposite directions. Fig. A.1 shows the 
twin half-edge corresponding to the half-edge ’e’. In the following, we 
extract the DCEL data structure for the VD through the proposed data 
structure: 
In the proposed data structure, the information of the DT constructed 
with points, and neighbors of each point are available counterclockwise 
in VM of it. On the other hand, both consecutive rows in this matrix 
show the information of vertices of the beginning and end of an edge of 
the Voronoi cell for that point, as the desired point is to the left of that 
edge. Thus, the information of each half-edge in the VD can be extracted 
from the VM of only one point. Hence, to extract the DCEL data structure from the proposed data structure, we first assign a unique ID to each 
half-edge. In this way, a column to the VM of each point is added (this 
column can be removed at the end). In each row of this column, the 
unique ID of one half-edge of the Voronoi cell of that point is placed. 
Then, to extract the DCEL data structure of VD, we need to find the ID of 
the beginning and end vertices of each half-edge, the face ID of the left 
and right side of each half-edge, the ID of the half-edge before and after 
each half-edge (e.prev and e.next respectively in Fig. A.1) and the ID of 
twin edge of each half-edge. 
Starting from the first half-edge mentioned in the first row of the VM 
of point ’1′, and respectively, we extract the required information for

__data__.text:
Advances in Engineering Software 169 (2022) 103129
15•IDs of beginning and ending vertices: Considering that in the pro-
posed data structure, the ID of vertices of Voronoi cell for any point 
in the third column of VM is listed counterclockwise from top to 
bottom. it can be assumed that the ID listed in the third column of the 
row corresponds to each half-edge is the vertex ID of the beginning of 
that half-edge. In addition, the ID mentioned in the third column of 
the next row corresponding to each half-edge is the vertex ID of the 
end of that half-edge.  
•Left and right face IDs: Left face ID is the point ID where the row 
corresponding to the desired half-edge is in the VM of that point. The 
vertex ID of the beginning and end of each half-edge is the ID of two 
adjacent Delaunay triangles corresponding to those two vertices, and 
on the other hand, these two adjacent triangles are common on one 
edge and two points (For example, edge 34–37 in Fig. A.1 for two 
triangles corresponding to the beginning and end of the vertices of 
the half-edge e). One of the common points has the right side face ID 
and the other has the left side face ID of the desired half-edge. 
Simply, the ID of the right side face of each half-edge is in the sec-
ond column of the row corresponding to that half-edge placed in the 
VM of the left face.  
•Before and after half-edge ID: they are placed in the row before and 
after the row corresponding to that half-edge in the VM and the 
fourth column.  
•Twin ID: Considering that the end vertex of each half-edge is the 
beginning vertex of the twin corresponding to that half-edge, the 
twin ID of each half-edge is in the fourth column of the VM of the face 
on the right side of that half-edge, which the end vertex ID of the 
desired half-edge is in the third column of that. 
In this way, it is possible to extract all information required for the 
DCEL data structure of VD from the proposed data structure with the 
overall complexity of O(n).

；
４ １ ８ ０ １ ３ １ ８
；
４１６７１３８３
）
摘
　
要
：
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图是计算几何学中一个重要数据结构
，
在诸多领域具有广泛的应用
。
栅格扫描算法符
合计算机离散特征
，
优化了欧氏距离算法
，
是最优的栅格
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图生成算法之一
。
但是
，
由于栅格单
元距离与欧氏距离的差异
，
在扫描过程中部分单元的归属不可避免地产生一定的误差
，
使栅格
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图的应用受到一定限制
。
本文针对传统扫描算法存在的误差缺陷
，
提出了一种基于横
－
纵扫描的栅格
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图改进生成算法
。
首先
，
深入分析了传统扫描算法产生误差缺陷的原因和区域分布特征
；
然
后
，
以
３
"
３
邻域为模板
，
在一个正常周期的水平
（
横向
）
扫描后
，
增加一个周期竖直
（
纵向
）
扫描
，
即通过
横
－
纵两个周期扫描实现
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图的准确生成
；
最后
，
应用不同的栅格数据进行了试验对比
，
结果表
明
：
改进后的算法既具备扫描算法效率上的优势
，
同时解决了原算法扫描的误差缺陷
，
在高效生成的同
时把误差限制在一个格网以内
。
关键词
：
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图
；
光栅扫描
；
栅格距离

Ｍ ａ ｒ ｃ ｈ
　
２ ０ １ ９Ｖ ｏ ｌ ． ４ ８Ｎ ｏ． ３ＡＧ Ｃ Ｓ
　
ｈ ｔ ｔｐ
：
∥
ｘ ｂ． ｓ ｉ ｎ ｏ ｍ ａ ｐｓ ． ｃ ｏ ｍ
中图分类号
：
Ｐ ２ ０ ８
　　　　
文献标识码
：
Ａ
　　　　
文章编号
：
１ ０ ０ １
－
１ ５ ９ ５
（
２ ０ １ ９
）
０ ３
－
０ ３ ９ ３
－
０ ７
基金项目
：
国家重点研发计划
（
２ ０ １ ８ Ｙ Ｆ Ｂ ０ ５ ０ ５ ３ ０ １
） ；
国家自然科学基金
（
４ １ ６ ７ １ ３ ９ ４
；
４ １ ８ ０ １ ３ １ ８
；
４１６７１３８３
）
　　
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图
（
简称
Ｖ
图
）
是计算几何学中一个
重要的数据结构
，
具有自然邻近
、
动态稳定等特
性
，
在计算机图形学
、
地理信息系统
、
生态学
、
分子
化学
、
气象学
、
机械
、
医学
、
艺术等领域得到了广泛
应用
［
１
－
６
］
。
其中
，
Ｖ
图结构的高效
、
准确生成是其
诸多应用顺利实现的关键
。
国内外学者对
Ｖ
图
生成算法进行了许多研究
，
其成果主要分为矢量
算法和栅格算法两类
。
经典矢量算法包括分治算法
［
７
］
、
插入算法
［
８
］
、
扫描线算法
［
９
］
、
投影算法
［
１ ０
］
等
。
矢量算法对生长
元有一定的局限性
［
１ １
］
，
只能将点和线段
（
或半线
）
作为生长元处理
，
较难生成线集图
［
１ ２
］
，
对于面和
其他更复杂的空间目标要将其分解为点和线后才
能处理
，
这种分解严重地破坏了空间生长目标的
完整性
。
矢量算法不仅算法复杂
，
而且产生的数
据结构复杂
，
不利于海量数据的处理
［
１ ３
］
。
为弥补矢量算法的不足
，
许多学者提出了基
于栅格数据的
Ｖ
图生成算法
。
栅格
Ｖ
图生成算
法的关键是为每个格网找到距其最近的种子点
（
或线
、
面
） 。
依据格网得到种子点归属方法的不
同
，
现有栅格
Ｖ
图生成算法可分为
３
类
。

__data__.text:
矢量算法不仅算法复杂
，
而且产生的数
据结构复杂
，
不利于海量数据的处理
［
１ ３
］
。
为弥补矢量算法的不足
，
许多学者提出了基
于栅格数据的
Ｖ
图生成算法
。
栅格
Ｖ
图生成算
法的关键是为每个格网找到距其最近的种子点
（
或线
、
面
） 。
依据格网得到种子点归属方法的不
同
，
现有栅格
Ｖ
图生成算法可分为
３
类
。
第一类
算法
，
是较为传统的通过多边形的扩张和距离变
换来得到
Ｖ
图
，
如距离变换算法
［
１ ３
－
１ ４
］
、
扩张算
法
［
１ ５
－
１ ６
］
等
。
这类算法通过使用栅格距离代替欧
氏距离来提升效率
，
所用模板有棋盘距离
、
城市距
离
、
八角距离等
。
这些距离指标只是最优距离度
量
（
欧几里得距离
）
的粗略近似
。
这类算法的误差
很难控制
，
随着格网和种子点数量增多而加大
。
第二类算法是利用四叉树等数据结构通过区域划
分并判断区域归属的方式来得到
Ｖ
图
，
如层次算
法
［
１ ７
－
１ ８
］
、
细分算法
［
１ ９
］
等
。
此类算法大多较为复
杂
，
不同层次
、
区域拓扑关系不明朗
，
且很难动态

综合精度和效率因素
，
栅格扫描算法是最优
的栅格
Ｖ
图生成算法之一
。
此类算法通常利用邻域模板对所有格网进行向前向后两次扫描得到
Ｖ
图

，

氏距离算法
，
在大数据量情况下

较其他第三类栅

２ ５
］

２ ６

。
然而

在地图
、
军事
、
医学

３
－
５
］
等高精度领域的应用
中
，
Ｖ
图的误差可能会造成严重的后果
。
例如
，
在海洋划界工作中
，
Ｖ
图是问题的理想解决办
法
［
６
］

不过
，
在海洋区域的划界中出现任何位置

，

，
而损害另一
个国家的海洋空间
。

经济
、
军事活动和国家关系产生严重影响
。
为此
，
本文提出了一种基于横
－

Ｖ

，

域特征

增
加一个周期竖直
（
纵向
）
扫描
，
实现栅格
Ｖ
图的高
效
、
准确生成
，
并把误差控制在一个格网以内
，
最
后进行了试验对比分析
。

传统扫描算法原理及缺陷

与矢量空间

Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
区域
。
根据这个特点
，
利用邻近格网之

，
格网就可以从它邻近格网

Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
区域

子点进行距离比较

２ ２

原理是通过一个
３
"
３
的邻域模板将一个格网的信息传递给它的邻近格
网
（
如图
１
所示
） 。

Ｑ ２
这
４
个邻近格网中得到其最近种子点
。
正反
两次扫描称为一个竖直扫描周期
。
与水平扫描周期相同
，
竖直扫描周期正反扫
描同样具有类似的过程
，
其结果如图
７
所示
，
其中

（
ａ

，
图
７
（
ｂ
）
为单次
反向扫描后的结果
。
水平扫描后接竖直扫描的解决方案对一个格
网进行两个周期共
４
次扫描
，
可以完全覆盖该种
子点周围所有区域
，
如图
８
所示
。
蓝色格网为竖
直周期正向扫描覆盖区域
，
绿色格网为竖直周期
反向扫描覆盖区域
，
紫色区域为他们重合区域
。
左侧的浅绿色区域
（
Ⅰ
区
）
和右侧的浅蓝色区域
（
Ⅱ
区
）
为水平周期无法完全覆盖的区域
，
但是可
以被竖直周期覆盖
。
这样就保证了种子点周围所
有区域在经过水平
、
竖直两个周期扫描后都可以
得到该种子点
。

４
　
结
　
论
本文在深入分析了传统扫描算法产生误差缺
陷的原因和区域特征后
，
在传统栅格扫描算法基础
上
，
提出了一种基于横
－
纵扫描的
Ｖ
图生成改进算
法
，
并进行了相关效率和精度试验
，
结果表明
：
（
１
）
改进后的算法保留了扫描算法效率上的
优势
，
在大数据量情况下速度远高于确定归属算法
，
与原扫描算法的效率基本一致
。
（
２
）
改进后算法弥补了原算法不完备的扫描
缺陷
，
在高效生成的同时把误差限制在一个格网
以内
，
达到了与确定归属算法相当的精度
。

__data__.text:
收稿日期： 2012-09-02；定稿日期： 2012-01-25 
基金项目： 国家自然科学基金资助项目（ 61272309 ，61070135 ） 
  作者简介： 寿华好（ 1964-），男，浙江诸暨人，教授，博士，主要研究方向为计算机辅助几何设计与图形学。 E-mail：shh@zjut.edu.cn V oronoi图的应用领域非常广泛，在 Vo r o n o i
图明确定义以前， 1644年法国数学家 Descartes（笛卡尔）发表的太阳系及其周边天体的发布
图，就是一种 V oronoi 图，而且还是一种加权一种平面点集 Vo ro n o i图的细分算法  
寿华好1， 袁子薇1， 缪永伟2， 王丽萍3 
（1. 浙江工业大学理学院，浙江  杭州  310023； 
2. 浙江工业大学计算机科学与技术学院，浙江  杭州  310023； 
3. 浙江工业大学经贸管理学院，浙江  杭州  310023） 
摘      要： V oronoi图是计算几何中的重要概念之一，在计算机图形学、计算几何、
计算机辅助几何设计、有限元网格划分、机器人轨迹控制、模式识别、气象学和地质学研究中得到广泛应用。借助于四叉树和区间算术，提出了一种新的构造平面点集 V oronoi图的细
分算法 , 并且和经典的增量算法、栅格扩张法进行了比较 , 结果显示新细分算法更为有效。
最重要的是细分算法原理简单，很容易编程实现。  
关  键  词： V oronoi图；细分算法；增量算法；栅格扩张法；区间算术  
中图分类号： TP 391.72 
文献标识码： A         文 章 编 号： 2095-302X (2013)02-0001-06 
 
A Subdivision Algorithm for Voronoi Diagram of Planar Point Set 
 
Shou Huahao1,  Yuan Ziwei1,  Miao Yongwei2,  Wang Liping3 
 ( 1. College of Science, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou Zhejiang 310023, China; 
2. College of Computer Science and Technology, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou Zhejiang 310023, China; 
3. College of Business and Administration, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou Zhejiang 310023, China ) 
   
Abstract: V oronoi diagram is one of the most important concepts in computational geometry, 
It is applied widely in computer graphics, computational geometry, computer aided geometric 
design, finite element grid partition, robot trajectory control, pattern recognition, meteorology and geology. Based on quadtree data structure and interval arithmetic technique, a new subdivision 
algorithm for V oronoi diagram of a planar point se t is proposed. A comparison of this subdivision 
algorithm with the well known incremental algorithm and grid expansion method is conducted. Test results show that the subdivision algorithm is more efficient. The most important is that the idea of subdivision algorithm is very simple and therefore it is easy to implement.

Abstract: V oronoi diagram is one of the most important concepts in computational geometry, 
It is applied widely in computer graphics, computational geometry, computer aided geometric

Key words:  V oronoi diagram; subdivision algorithm; incremental algorithm; grid expansion

__data__.text:
V oronoi图[1]。1932年B.N.Delone 给出了 “V oronoi
区域 ”的概念，标志着 Vo r o n o i图作为计算几何的
一个研究分支的正式诞生[1]。其后在生物学、化
学、流体力学、医学等诸多领域得到广泛应用。
作为当前计算几何学科的一个研究热点，就其重要性来说， V oronoi 图是仅次于凸壳的一个重要
的几何结构
[2]。在不同的领域， V oronoi图有时也
被称为 Thiessen 多边形[1]、Dirichrit 网格、或
Wigner-Seitz 域等[3]。V oronoi图的基本定义和算
法可见于许多计算几何教科书。它是关于空间邻
近关系一种基础数据结构。 V oronoi图有二维和
三维、狭义和广义、一阶和高阶之分[2]。其中最
基本、应用最广泛和研究最深入的还是二维欧氏
空间平面点集 V oronoi 图，平面线集和面集
V oronoi图可以通过平面点集 V oronoi图处理近似
获得[4]。平面点集 V oronoi图常用构造算法主要
包括矢量方法[3]和栅格方法[5-6]，基于矢量的方法
有对偶生成法、增量构造算法、分治法、减量算
法、平面扫描算法[3]；基于栅格的方法有邻域栅
格扩张法和栅格邻近归属法[5-6]。在矢量方法中，
增量构造算法的时间复杂度在最坏的情况下为
O(n2)，其中 n为平面点集中点的个数，在一般情  
况下其运行时间为3
2()On，在改进的 V oronoi图
增量构造方法中，时间复杂度为 (l o g)On n[7]，分  
治法、减量算法和平面扫描算法的时间复杂度为
(l o g 2)On n ，间接法的时间复杂度取决于其对偶
Delaunay 三角网获取的时间复杂度[6, 8]。国内外
研究者根据其应用对传统的 V oronoi 划分或
Delaunay 三角剖分算法进行了一系列的改  
进[9-11]。栅格法与矢量法相比 ,思想较为简单，易
于向三维空间扩展，但是它的精度受到栅格单元大小的限制，一般耗时长，精度不高
[12-13]，栅格
法中相对比较新的方法为一种经过改进的栅格
扩张法[13]，其时间复杂度为22()Om n −，其中 m
为栅格的总数量。

研究者根据其应用对传统的 V oronoi 划分或

进[9-11]。栅格法与矢量法相比 ,思想较为简单，易
于向三维空间扩展，但是它的精度受到栅格单元大小的限制，一般耗时长，精度不高
[12-13]，栅格
法中相对比较新的方法为一种经过改进的栅格

为栅格的总数量。我们在本文中提出的平面点集
V oronoi图的细分算法是一种全新的栅格法，由
于我们在细分算法中使用了四叉树和区间算术，当判断出某一平面区域中没有
Vo r o n o i图的时候
可以整个地把这个平面区域抛掉，不需要对每一个栅格一个一个地处理，从而极大地提高了栅格法的计算速度，这一点在我们所运行的实例中可以看得很清楚。此外，更重要的是细分算法原理更为简单，非常容易编程实现。细分算法在最坏

候由于细分算法可以成片地抛掉不包含 V oronoi图的平面区域，从而实际计算量远远小于这个
数。  
在V oronoi图中，被用来划分空间的各个基
本图形元素一般被称为站点。最基本的 V oronoi 
图是以平面点集 { }n ip pi ,2,1," = = 为站点的
V oronoi 图，它将平面划分成凸多边形形状的
V oronoi 区域， p中的每个站点ip，对应一个这
样区域  iv，使得  iv内的任何点距离ip比距离其  
它站点近。本文的基本思想是在给定的矩形区域  
中找出所有到站点ip的最短距离至少在两处或  
以上达到的像素（也就是栅格）集合，此像素集
合即是平面点集 p的Vo r o n o i图，在求解过程中
借助于四叉树数据结构和区间运算技术进行加速
[14]。

面矩形区域内到这些点的最短距离至少有两处或两处以上达到的像素点全体。

1） 输入 n个平面点111(, )pxy ，222(, )pxy …

[],xxy y⎡⎤×⎣⎦，如果 [, ]gg与[,] , 1iiggi n≤≤中
至少两个区间相交，则将区域 [],xxy y⎡⎤×⎣⎦在其  
中点处一分为四个小区域，对每个小区域重复步
骤2），一直细分到区域的大小为小于等于一个像
素的大小 ε为止，如果还是排除不掉，则将其存
入M。 
3） 画出111(, )pxy，222(, )pxy… (, )nnnpxy  
以及 V oronoi图M，算法结束。  
以上细分算法充分利用了 V oronoi区域的连贯  
性，当算法判断出某矩形区域 [],xxy y⎡⎤×⎣⎦内不  
可能包含 Vo r o n o i图的时候，可以把整个矩形区  
域[],xxy y⎡⎤×⎣⎦丢掉，从而运行效率比较高。  
由于到目前为止，虽然构造平面点集 V oronoi
图的算法有很多，但是经典的增量算法是最常用
的构造 Vo r o n o i图的方法[7]。栅格法也出现了很多
新的算法，本文对比的就是一种新的栅格扩张方法。我们考虑将这里新提出的细分算法与增量算法、栅格扩张法作一个比较，以便通过比较看一看细分算法的表现如何。
 经典增量算法的基本思
想是：在已构造的输入了站点的 Vo r o n o i图的基础
上, 逐步加入新的站点 , 再利用局部特性 , 通过局
部修改已有的 V oronoi图来生成新的 Voronoi图，  
即对于平面离散的站点集合 {}np pp ,2 1"，在站
点集合 {}ip pp ,2 1" ()ni<的V oronoi图的基础
上, 再加入新的站点1+ip, 然后通过局部修改来  
构造{}1 2 1 ,+i ipp pp" 的Vo r o n o i图。如此不断  
加入新的站点 , 最后即可得到点集 {}np pp ,2 1"  
的V oronoi图[7]。

例3  输入 10点： { }10.35, 0 ,p= { }20.25, 0.45 , p=  
{ }30.5,1 , p=  { }4 0.75,0.5 , p= { }50.85,0.1 , p=  
{ } { }670.15,0.3 , 0.95,0.65 , pp== { }8 0.4,0.2 , p=  
{ }90.6,0.7 , p=  { }10 1, 0.8 , p= 图7为增量算法的  
结果，图 8为细分算法的结果，图 9为栅格扩张
法的结果。  
 
图9  10个点的 V oronoi图（栅格扩张法）  
 CPU Time Used: 85742.2 Second 
 
图10  100个点的 V oronoi图（细分算法）  
   CPU Time Used: 144.394 Second 
为了说明细分算法的有效性我们还特别增
加了一个多点 V oronoi图的例子。  
例4  随机产生的 100个点，图10为细分算
法结果。  
4  结  论 
从以上实例可以看出，本文提出的细分算法
可以有效的计算出平面点集的 V oronoi图，并且细
分算法的运算速度比栅格扩张法要快很多，比经典的增量算法也要快，从算法复杂度分析可以看出增量算法的计算时间随着点数的增加以平方的速度增加，而细分算法的计算时间只是线性地增加，从而多点的时候细分算法的优势就更明显。最重要的是细分算法思想十分简单，非常容易编程实现，而增量算法和栅格扩张法的原理相对比较复杂，实现起来要麻烦多了。此外需要指出的是细分算法得到的是一个包含
V oronoi图的像素点
的集合，由于区间算术的保守性， 部分邻近 V oronoi
图但是不应包含于 V oronoi图的像素点有可能会因
为无法排除而被保留了下来，这使得用细分算法第 2 期                      寿华好等：一种平面点集 V oronoi图的细分算法                       ·5·

3  结 束 语 
国际班工程图学课程借鉴国外同类课程的教
学经验，顺应生产设计实践中以三维参数化造型
设计为主流的现实，在兼顾工程制图基本功训练
的同时，以熟练读取工程图和使用三维造型软件设计并生成清晰、规范的工程图，同时具备一定
的尺规作图和草图能力为教学目标。 引入参数化、
变量化概念，加强设计及表达的理念，使学生通过本课程的学习具备较强的设计和表达基础。
 
针对课程的教学目标，选用及设计了和工程
实际密切相关的教学资源，采用面向教学目标、在过程中穿插基础知识点的教学安排，增强学生
兴趣。全英文授课，通过面向教学目标讲解制图
标准，通过讲透一套标准然后讲清国标和美标关系加强学生对标准的理解，有利学生对标准的掌
握，培养学生的专业国际交流基础。采用长时段的上机实操考核学生的读图、造型设计和表达的
综合能力，较传统的考核方式可以更好地检验教学目标。

随着全球生态环境
、
社会经济一体化的不断深入
，
研
究区域逐渐从局部区域扩大到整个地球
，
而摄影测量
、
遥
感
、
全球定位系统等现代对地观测技术的快速发展
，
使得
全球大范围
、
多尺度
、
多时相数据的获取成为可能
。
为了
在全球范围内有效地管理和分析空间数据
，
需要构建一
个全 球 的
、
连 续 的
、
多尺度的动态数据模型
。
球 面
Ｖ ｏ ｒ ｏ ｎ ｏ ｉ
图
（
简称
Ｖ
图
） ，
具有自然邻近
、
动态稳定等优良
特性
，
已成为全球空间信息管理与分析最有潜力的解决
方案之一
。
针对现有的球面
Ｖ
图生成算法在精度和效率
方面存在的诸多问题
，
本文从球面
Ｖ
图的生成算法
、
动态
维护及其应用方面进行了研究
，
主要内容如下
：
（
１
）
提出了基于
ＱＴＭ
的球面
Ｖ
图确定归属生成算
法
。
本文将球面四元三角格网
（
ｑｕ ａ ｔ ｅ ｒ ｎ ａ ｒ ｙ
　
ｔ ｒ ｉ ａ ｎｇｕ ｌ ａ ｒ
ｍ ｅ ｓ ｈ
，
ＱＴＭ
）
单元视作平面栅格算法中的像素
（
最小单
元
） ，
计算每个格网单元到所有种子点的距离
，
并通过比
较得到最近的种子点作为相应
ＱＴＭ
格网单元的归属
，
从
而生成基于
ＱＴＭ
的球面
Ｖ
图
。
试验结果表明
，
该算法
能够将生成球面
Ｖ
图的误差控制在两个格网以内
，
初步
解决了现有球面
Ｖ
图栅格生成算法的精度问题
。
（
２
）
利用
Ｇ ＰＵ
对确定归属算法进行了优化
（
硬件优
化
） 。

、

独立性的特点
，

模型
。

（
ＣＵＤＡ
）
对算法
进行实现
，
并从
Ｇ ＰＵ
